title: General Knowledge Quiz XIV (50 Questions)
description: Challenging but fair across medicine, music, grammar, exploration, and AI history. No sports content.

items.q: Which organ filters blood to produce urine and regulate electrolytes?
items.a: Kidneys - paired organs essential for homeostasis

items.q: What is the medical term for a heart attack?
items.a: Myocardial infarction - interruption of blood flow to heart muscle

items.q: Which vitamin deficiency leads to rickets in children?
items.a: Vitamin D deficiency - impaired bone mineralization

items.q: What is hypertension commonly defined as (mmHg) for adults?
items.a: Consistently ≥130/80 or ≥140/90 depending on guideline - elevated arterial pressure

items.q: Which type of blood vessel carries blood away from the heart?
items.a: Arteries - thick‑walled vessels under higher pressure

items.q: What does MRI stand for in medical imaging?
items.a: Magnetic Resonance Imaging - uses strong magnets and radio waves

items.q: Which pathogen causes tuberculosis?
items.a: Mycobacterium tuberculosis - acid‑fast bacillus affecting lungs

items.q: What is the body’s first line of defense against pathogens?
items.a: Innate immune system - barriers like skin, mucosa, and nonspecific responses

items.q: Which hormone regulates basal metabolic rate and is produced by the thyroid gland?
items.a: Thyroxine (T4) - converted to the more active T3 in tissues

items.q: What is the term for surgical removal of the appendix?
items.a: Appendectomy - treatment for appendicitis

items.q: How many semitones are in a Western octave?
items.a: Twelve - forms the chromatic scale

items.q: Which composer wrote the opera The Marriage of Figaro?
items.a: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart - premiered in 1786

items.q: What is the term for gradually getting louder in music notation?
items.a: Crescendo - the opposite is diminuendo

items.q: Which Baroque composer wrote The Four Seasons?
items.a: Antonio Vivaldi - a set of violin concertos (c. 1725)

items.q: What is the highest standard female voice type?
items.a: Soprano - above mezzo‑soprano and contralto

items.q: Which German composer wrote the Brandenburg Concertos?
items.a: Johann Sebastian Bach - six concertos dedicated to Christian Ludwig

items.q: What do we call a short musical idea recurring throughout a composition?
items.a: Motif - fundamental building block of themes

items.q: Which 20th‑century composer pioneered minimalism with works like Einstein on the Beach?
items.a: Philip Glass - repetitive structures and additive processes

items.q: What is the Italian term for ‘at first sight’ used for reading music?
items.a: A prima vista - sight‑reading

items.q: Which Romantic composer wrote the symphonic poem Also sprach Zarathustra famously used in 2001: A Space Odyssey?
items.a: Richard Strauss - tone poem from 1896

items.q: What punctuation marks set off a nonessential clause within a sentence?
items.a: Commas (or em dashes/parentheses) - indicate nonrestrictive information

items.q: Which term describes a word that modifies a verb, adjective, or another adverb?
items.a: Adverb - often ends in ‑ly in English

items.q: What is the proper term for the ‘to’ form of a verb (e.g., to run)?
items.a: Infinitive - base form preceded by ‘to’ in English

items.q: Which mood expresses wishes, demands, or hypotheticals (e.g., “If I were…”)
items.a: Subjunctive mood - distinct forms in certain verbs

items.q: What is the difference between ‘its’ and ‘it’s’?
items.a: ‘Its’ is possessive; ‘it’s’ is a contraction of ‘it is’ or ‘it has’

items.q: What do we call a word spelled the same but with different meanings (e.g., bat the animal vs. bat for baseball)?
items.a: Homonym - context clarifies meaning

items.q: Which punctuation mark indicates omitted material in a quotation?
items.a: Ellipsis (…) - also suggests trailing off in informal writing

items.q: What is a sentence lacking a main clause called?
items.a: Fragment - missing subject, predicate, or complete thought

items.q: What is the Oxford (serial) comma used for?
items.a: To clarify lists of three or more items by adding a comma before ‘and’ or ‘or’

items.q: Which punctuation mark joins two independent clauses more strongly than a comma but less finally than a period?
items.a: Semicolon - links closely related clauses

items.q: Who completed the first solo nonstop transatlantic flight in 1927?
items.a: Charles Lindbergh - flew the Spirit of St. Louis from New York to Paris

items.q: Which Portuguese navigator rounded the Cape of Good Hope in 1488?
items.a: Bartolomeu Dias - opened a sea route to the Indian Ocean

items.q: Which expedition first reached the geographic South Pole in 1911?
items.a: Roald Amundsen’s team - beat Scott by about a month

items.q: Which instrument measures a ship’s latitude by the Sun or stars?
items.a: Sextant - angle‑measuring tool for celestial navigation

items.q: Which 15th‑century prince sponsored voyages along Africa’s coast?
items.a: Prince Henry the Navigator - Portuguese patron of exploration

items.q: Which Chinese admiral led early 15th‑century treasure voyages in the Indian Ocean?
items.a: Zheng He - eunuch admiral of the Ming dynasty

items.q: What line at 0° latitude circles the Earth midway between the poles?
items.a: The Equator - defines northern and southern hemispheres

items.q: Which cartographer introduced a cylindrical map projection useful for navigation in 1569?
items.a: Gerardus Mercator - preserves rhumb lines as straight

items.q: Which Norwegian explorer crossed Greenland’s ice sheet in 1888?
items.a: Fridtjof Nansen - pioneering polar scientist and humanitarian

items.q: Which Spanish explorer reached the Pacific across Panama in 1513?
items.a: Vasco Núñez de Balboa - first European to see the Pacific from the New World

items.q: Who proposed the ‘imitation game’ as a test for machine intelligence in 1950?
items.a: Alan Turing - suggested an operational test of indistinguishability in conversation

items.q: Which 1956 summer workshop is often cited as the birth of AI as a field?
items.a: The Dartmouth Conference - organized by McCarthy, Minsky, Rochester, and Shannon

items.q: Which computer defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov in 1997?
items.a: IBM’s Deep Blue - milestone in game‑playing AI

items.q: Which algorithm, introduced by Rumelhart, Hinton, and Williams (1986), trains multi‑layer neural nets?
items.a: Backpropagation - gradient‑based learning via chain rule

items.q: What is the term for training a model on labeled examples?
items.a: Supervised learning - mapping inputs to outputs

items.q: Which 2012 breakthrough used deep convolutional nets to win ImageNet?
items.a: AlexNet - by Krizhevsky, Sutskever, and Hinton

items.q: Which 2016 system defeated Go champion Lee Sedol?
items.a: DeepMind’s AlphaGo - combined deep learning with Monte Carlo tree search

items.q: What does NLP stand for in computer science?
items.a: Natural Language Processing - enabling computers to understand human language

items.q: What architecture introduced ‘self‑attention’ and the slogan ‘Attention Is All You Need’ (2017)?
items.a: The Transformer - Vaswani et al., core of modern language models

items.q: Which open‑source library from Google popularized tensor computation for ML?
items.a: TensorFlow - widely used framework for building and training models
